conclusion: The problem involves analyzing the relationship between the terminal voltage and current of a power source and resistors to maximize the power-source output efficiency.
The graph shows the terminal voltage \\( U \\) versus the current \\( I \\) for the power source and resistors \\( R_1 \\) and \\( R_2 \\).
The power source has an open-circuit voltage \\( E = 3 \\) V and a short-circuit current \\( I_{\text{sc}} = 6 \\) A.
The internal resistance \\( r \\) of the power source is \\( 0.5 \\) Ω.
The line representing \\( R_1 \\) passes through \\( (0, 0) \\) and \\( (2, 1) \\), indicating \\( R_1 = 0.5 \\) Ω.
The line representing \\( R_2 \\) passes through \\( (0, 0) \\) and \\( (2, 2) \\), indicating \\( R_2 = 1 \\) Ω.
The total resistance when \\( R_1 \\) and \\( R_2 \\) are in series is \\( 1.5 \\) Ω.
The current through the circuit when \\( R_1 \\) and \\( R_2 \\) are in series is approximately \\( 1.5 \\) A.
The terminal voltage when \\( R_1 \\) and \\( R_2 \\) are in series is approximately \\( 2.25 \\) V.
The power output when \\( R_1 \\) and \\( R_2 \\) are in series is approximately \\( 3.375 \\) W.
The equivalent resistance when \\( R_1 \\) and \\( R_2 \\) are in parallel is approximately \\( 0.333 \\) Ω.
The current through the circuit when \\( R_1 \\) and \\( R_2 \\) are in parallel is approximately \\( 3.6 \\) A.
The terminal voltage when \\( R_1 \\) and \\( R_2 \\) are in parallel is approximately \\( 1.2 \\) V.
The power output when \\( R_1 \\) and \\( R_2 \\) are in parallel is approximately \\( 4.32 \\) W.
The maximum power output is achieved when \\( R_1 \\) and \\( R_2 \\) are connected in parallel.
